appearance of the todo list application. These key-value pair settings

Each configuration is identified by a unique name that serves as the

Regular indexes on created_at and updated_at fields optimize queries

redeployment. Configuration settings might include UI themes, feature
toggles, rate limiting values, or integration endpoints.

role able to read or modify configuration settings. This security

ITodoListChannel.description:
Organizational containers that help users categorize and manage their
todo lists. Channels provide visual grouping with customizable themes and
serve as a discovery mechanism for shared task lists.

Each channel has a unique code identifier used in APIs and URLs instead
of numeric IDs to prevent enumeration attacks and provide user-friendly
sharing links. The name and description fields help users understand
the channel's purpose and content.

Visual properties like color and icon provide immediate visual recognition,
enabling users to quickly identify channels in their interface. These
properties support customization of the user experience and help
organize tasks into meaningful categories.

The entity supports soft deletion through the deleted_at timestamp,
allowing for potential recovery of accidentally deleted channels while
removing them from active use. Indexes on name and description fields
using GIN with trigram operations enable efficient text search with
fuzzy matching.

Channels are associated with a specific user who created them through
the todo_list_channels relation in the todo_list_user entity. This
ownership model determines who can modify or delete a channel.

Access control is enforced at the API level, with only authenticated
users able to read or modify channel data. Owners have full control
over their channels, while other users may have limited access
based on sharing mechanisms not represented in this schema.

The code field is particularly important for security, as using
guessable numeric IDs could allow attackers to enumerate all channels
in the system. The unique code serves as a "security through obscurity"
layer, making it harder to discover channels without proper access.

Channels play a crucial role in user experience by providing
organization and visual distinction between different types of
tasks or projects. A user might have separate channels for work,
personal tasks, shopping, and hobbies, each with distinct visual
styling for easy identification.

identification and authentication details.

The schema represents the todo_list_user entity which serves as the
foundation for user authentication and personalization in the
application.

Each user is identified by a UUID primary key, ensuring global
uniqueness and security through obscurity compared to sequential
numeric IDs. The timestamps track the account's lifecycle, with
created_at marking when the account was registered and updated_at
recording the last modification time.

Soft deletion is supported through the optional deleted_at timestamp,
allowing for account recovery and preserving referential integrity
with related data like channels and tasks. When deleted_at is null,
the account is active; when it contains a timestamp, the account
is considered inactive.

The entity includes relationships with other entities through the
Prisma schema, though these are not represented as properties in
this JSON schema. The todo_list_channels relation indicates that
a user can own multiple channels.

registration date, which is useful for analyzing user growth
patterns or implementing retention features.

Security considerations include protecting user data through
authentication and authorization. Only authenticated users can
access their own account information, and administrative functions
may allow viewing user data for support purposes.

The schema intentionally excludes authentication credentials like
passwords or tokens, which are stored in separate, more securely
protected systems. This separation of concerns enhances security
by minimizing the exposure of sensitive authentication data.

User accounts serve as the anchor for all personalized features
in the application, from task ownership to notification preferences.
They enable collaboration by identifying contributors and owners
in shared spaces like channels.

The minimal design of the user schema reflects a focus on core
account data, with additional profile information potentially
stored in separate entities if needed. This keeps the primary

Represents the data required to create a new user account.

The system follows a zero-knowledge architecture for user
credentials, meaning the application never sees or stores
passwords directly. Instead, it relies on OAuth, OpenID Connect,
or similar protocols to handle authentication, receiving only
validated identity information after successful login.

When a user signs in for the first time, the system creates a
todo_list_user record with a UUID identifier and timestamps,
associating the external identity with the application's data
model. This approach eliminates the need for a traditional
registration form and reduces security risks associated with
password storage and management.

The empty creation schema reflects this architectural decision,
indicating that user creation is not a direct API operation
but rather a side effect of successful authentication with
a trusted identity provider.

This design enhances security by removing the application's
responsibility for secure password hashing, storage, and
recovery. It also improves user experience by enabling
single sign-on and reducing friction in the onboarding
process.

Administrative operations can create user records directly
for testing or onboarding purposes, but this is not exposed
through the public API and follows different security protocols.

The approach aligns with modern identity management best
practices, leveraging specialized identity providers to handle
authentication complexity while the application focuses on
its core functionality.

ITodoListUser.IUpdate.description:

When a user updates their profile information (name, email,
profile picture, etc.) in the identity provider, those changes

This design decision follows the principle of single source
of truth for identity data. By allowing only the identity
provider to modify user profile information, the system ensures
consistency across all applications that use the same identity
provider.

ITokenValidationRequest.description:
Request payload for validating an authentication token.

This schema defines the structure of the request body for the
token validation endpoint. Clients must provide a valid JWT
(JSON Web Token) that was previously issued by the authentication
system.

The validation process checks several aspects of the token:

1. Signature verification to ensure the token has not been
tampered with
2. Expiration check to ensure the token is still valid
3. Revocation status check against active blacklists
4. Issuer validation to confirm the token came from a trusted source

The endpoint does not decode or inspect the token contents
beyond these validation checks, maintaining separation between
authentication and authorization concerns.

Security considerations include rate limiting to prevent abuse
of the validation endpoint, and ensuring the validation process
is resistant to timing attacks that could leak information
about token validity.

The simple structure reflects the focused purpose of the
endpoint - to verify token validity without unnecessary
complexity. Clients should already have the token from a
previous authentication operation.

No authentication is required for this endpoint itself, as
that would create a circular dependency where a token is
needed to validate a token. Instead, the endpoint relies
on the cryptographic security of the JWT standard.

The response will indicate only whether the token is currently
valid, without providing additional details that could aid
attackers in crafting valid tokens.

This design follows security best practices for token-based
authentication systems, providing a simple, efficient way
for clients to check token status before making authorized
API calls, thus avoiding unnecessary round trips with
authorization failures.

for re-authentication.

The exp and iat fields provide timestamp information in

token lifetime and understand when the token was originally
issued. This enables clients to make informed decisions
about when to refresh tokens proactively.

The user_id field identifies the authenticated user, allowing
clients to personalize the user interface without making
an additional API call to fetch user information.

The roles array contains the user's authorization roles,
which clients can use to enable or disable UI features
based on the user's permissions. This reduces the need
for additional authorization queries on application startup.

Security considerations include ensuring the response
contains no sensitive information beyond what is necessary
for client operation, and transmitting the response over
secure channels to prevent interception.

The comprehensive nature of the response helps clients
minimize API calls while maintaining up-to-date
authorization context. However, clients should still
perform server-side authorization checks for sensitive
operations, as client-side role information could be
tampered with.

The response serves as a "token introspection" endpoint,

the principle of least privilege in data disclosure.

IChangePasswordRequest.description:
Request payload for changing a user's password.

This schema defines the structure of the request body for
the password change endpoint. Users must provide both their
current password for verification and their desired new
password.

The current_password field is required to verify that the
user knows their existing credentials, preventing unauthorized
password changes even if an attacker gains access to an
active session.

The new_password field contains the desired replacement
password, which must meet the system's password policy
requirements (minimum length, complexity rules, etc.).

Security considerations include:

1. Requiring the current password to prevent session hijacking
attacks from changing passwords
2. Enforcing strong password policies for the new password
3. Hashing the new password using secure algorithms (bcrypt)
before storage
4. Invalidating all active sessions for the user after
password change to prevent use of potentially compromised
sessions
5. Rate limiting to prevent brute force attacks on the
password change endpoint

The endpoint requires authentication via a valid token,
but does not require administrative privileges, as users
should be able to manage their own credentials.

After successful password change, the system should trigger
security notifications to the user via email or other
registered contact methods to alert them of the change,
which could indicate either legitimate activity or a
compromised account.

Password history should be maintained to prevent reuse of
recent passwords, enhancing security by ensuring users
create genuinely new passwords rather than cycling through
a small set of familiar ones.

The response should not indicate whether the current password
was incorrect versus other errors to prevent user enumeration
attacks, returning a generic error message for all failure
cases.

This design follows security best practices for password
management, balancing user convenience with robust protection
against common attack vectors like credential stuffing,
password spraying, and session hijacking.

IChangePasswordResponse.description:
Response from the password change operation.

This schema defines the structure of the response from the
change password endpoint. It provides a simple success/failure
indicator with an optional descriptive message.

The success field is a boolean that indicates whether the
password change operation completed successfully. Clients
should treat false values as requiring user intervention,
either to correct input errors or to initiate account
recovery procedures.

The message field contains a human-readable description of
the result, which can provide additional context for the
user. For successful operations, this might confirm the
change; for failures, it might suggest corrective actions
without revealing sensitive information.

Security considerations include:

1. Not revealing specific reasons for failure (incorrect
current password vs. policy violation) to prevent
user enumeration and password spraying attacks
2. Using generic error messages for all failure cases
to avoid providing feedback that could aid attackers
3. Ensuring the response contains no sensitive information
about the user's account or previous passwords

The minimalist design reduces the attack surface by
minimizing information disclosure. Clients should handle
both technical errors (network issues, server errors)
and business logic errors (validation failures) through
the same response structure.

After a successful password change, clients should
invalidate local session tokens and prompt for
re-authentication, as the previous credentials are
no longer valid.

The response may trigger additional security processes
on the server side, such as logging the password change
for audit purposes, sending security notifications to
the user, and invalidating all active sessions to
prevent use of potentially compromised credentials.

This design prioritizes security over detailed error
feedback, following the principle that error messages
should be helpful to legitimate users but not informative
to potential attackers. The balance ensures users
understand when action is needed without providing
a roadmap for malicious actors.

IAuthResponse.description:
Authentication response containing JWT tokens.

This schema defines the standard response format for successful
authentication operations like login and registration. It
contains the tokens needed for maintaining a user session
and accessing protected resources.

The access_token is a JWT (JSON Web Token) that must be
included in the Authorization header of subsequent API calls
to access protected endpoints. It has a relatively short
expiration time (typically 15-60 minutes) to minimize the
security impact if it is compromised.

the current one expires, without requiring the user to
re-enter their credentials. It has a longer lifespan (typically
7-30 days) but can be revoked server-side if suspicious
activity is detected.

The expires_in field indicates how many seconds the access
token is valid for, allowing clients to plan proactive token
refresh before API calls start failing due to expiration.

which is Bearer for JWT tokens. This follows standard OAuth
2.0 conventions and ensures compatibility with HTTP client
libraries and API gateways.

1. Transmitting tokens only over HTTPS to prevent interception
2. Storing tokens securely on the client side (HTTP-only
cookies, secure storage)
3. Implementing token revocation mechanisms for logout and
security incidents
4. Using short-lived access tokens to minimize exposure
window
5. Binding refresh tokens to client characteristics when
possible to prevent token theft and replay

The response does not include user information to minimize
the risk of data exposure if the authentication response
is intercepted. Clients should use the /users/me endpoint
to retrieve user information after successful authentication.

This standardized response format is used across all
authentication endpoints (login, registration, token refresh)
to ensure consistent client implementation and predictable
behavior.

The token structure follows industry best practices for
OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect, balancing security requirements
with user experience considerations for maintaining
persistent sessions.

Client applications should implement token refresh logic

requests new access tokens before expiration, providing
a seamless user experience without requiring re-authentication
during normal usage patterns.

ITokenValidationRequest.description:
Represents a request to validate a JWT token.

This interface defines the data structure for validating an existing JWT
token to determine if it is still valid and hasn't been revoked. It
contains the token to be validated and any additional context needed for
the validation process.

The interface is designed specifically for use with the POST
/auth/user/validate endpoint. It allows clients to verify the validity of
a JWT token without requiring a full authentication process.

Security considerations include checking the token's digital signature to
ensure it hasn't been tampered with, validating the expiration timestamp
to prevent use of expired tokens, and potentially checking against a
revocation list if the system implements token invalidation.

This operation is useful for client-side applications to determine if a
stored token is still valid before making protected API calls, improving
user experience by avoiding failed requests due to expired tokens.

The token itself contains encoded user information, but this validation
ensures the token remains trustworthy according to the current security
policies of the system.

logic and JWT specification.

The system should hash the new password using a secure algorithm (like
bcrypt) before storing it. After successfully changing the password, the
system should invalidate all active sessions for that user to ensure that
potentially compromised sessions are terminated.

during transmission and at rest. The interface ensures that password
changes are authenticated and that new passwords meet security
requirements.

IAuthResponse.description:
Authentication response containing JWT tokens.

This schema defines the standard response format for successful
authentication operations like login and registration. It
contains the tokens needed for maintaining a user session
and accessing protected resources.

The access_token is a JWT (JSON Web Token) that must be
included in the Authorization header of subsequent API calls
to access protected endpoints. It has a relatively short
expiration time (typically 15-60 minutes) to minimize the
security impact if it is compromised.

The refresh_token is used to obtain new access tokens when
the current one expires, without requiring the user to
re-enter their credentials. It has a longer lifespan (typically
7-30 days) but can be revoked server-side if suspicious
activity is detected.

The expires_in field indicates how many seconds the access
token is valid for, allowing clients to plan proactive token
refresh before API calls start failing due to expiration.

The token_type field specifies the authentication scheme,
which is Bearer for JWT tokens. This follows standard OAuth
2.0 conventions and ensures compatibility with HTTP client
libraries and API gateways.

Security considerations include:

1. Transmitting tokens only over HTTPS to prevent interception
2. Storing tokens securely on the client side (HTTP-only
cookies, secure storage)
3. Implementing token revocation mechanisms for logout and
security incidents
4. Using short-lived access tokens to minimize exposure
window
5. Binding refresh tokens to client characteristics when
possible to prevent token theft and replay

The response does not include user information to minimize
the risk of data exposure if the authentication response
is intercepted. Clients should use the /users/me endpoint
to retrieve user information after successful authentication.

This standardized response format is used across all
authentication endpoints (login, registration, token refresh)
to ensure consistent client implementation and predictable
behavior.

The token structure follows industry best practices for
OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect, balancing security requirements
with user experience considerations for maintaining
persistent sessions.

Client applications should implement token refresh logic
that monitors the expires_in value and automatically
requests new access tokens before expiration, providing
a seamless user experience without requiring re-authentication
during normal usage patterns.
